channel.title: NYT > New York
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hochul Repeals Rule Allowing New Customers Free Gas Hookups
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul struck down a decades-old provision that raised gas bills for millions of New Yorkers. The move could help curb the use of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s repeal of a rule that allowed for free gas hookups for some new customers was applauded by climate activists and other supporters.

item.title: Hochul Reaches Deal on A.I. Regulation in New York
item.description: The bill, which lawmakers passed in June, will be modified to more closely match a similar law in California, at Big Tech’s urging.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul at Grand Central Terminal in December.

item.title: Immigration Officials Deport Queens 6-Year-Old and Father Who Fled China
item.description: Hundreds of people had rallied for the family in New York City after they were separated by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in November.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: ICE Detainee Dies After Being Held at a Troubled Jailhouse in Newark
item.description: Jean Wilson Brutus, 41, was one of four migrants to die in the past week after medical emergencies in detention centers in New Jersey, Michigan, Mississippi and Pennsylvania.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Delaney Hall detention center in Newark, where visitors regularly gather outside, a detainee from Haiti died soon after arriving last week.

item.title: Mamdani Revamps Hiring After Old Antisemitic Remarks Prompt Aide to Quit
item.description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani said he did not know about the antisemitic posts and would not have hired the woman who made them if he had.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catherine Almonte Da Costa, left, resigned a day after Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani appointed her to oversee administration hiring.

item.title: Hochul Expected to Veto Bill Requiring 2-Person Crews on Subway Trains
item.description: The bill, which would ensure that every train has a conductor and a driver, as most now do, was supported by the transit workers’ union and opposed by many transit advocates.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A conductor on an A train in Manhattan in March, 2024.

item.title: The MetroCard Cookie. The Pizza. The Carvel Treat.
item.description: The M.T.A. has worked with six food vendors to say goodbye to the MetroCard, memorialized in various treats.
item.dc:creator: James Barron
item.media:credit: James Barron/The New York Times

item.title: Elise Stefanik Drops Out of N.Y. Governor’s Race and Will Leave Congress
item.description: Ms. Stefanik, a Republican congresswoman and staunch ally of President Trump, abruptly ended her bid to unseat Gov. Kathy Hochul and said she would not seek another House term.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik is one of President Trump’s most steadfast supporters, but he had shied away from endorsing her in the New York governor’s race.

item.title: Federal Judge Overturns Conviction in Killing of D.J. Jam Master Jay
item.description: Karl Jordan Jr., godson of the musician, was convicted last year of murder in the service of a drug deal. The judge found that the government had not proved the motive.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar
item.media:credit: G. Paul Burnett/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jason Mizell, known as Jam Master Jay, created the beats for some of classic hip-hop’s best-known songs.

item.title: Mangione’s Lawyers Take Issue With Bondi’s Ties to UnitedHealthcare
item.description: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, say Attorney General Pam Bondi should have recused herself from the case.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi recently worked for a lobbying firm that lists UnitedHealthcare’s parent company among its clients.

item.title: Two NJ Transit Trains Collide, Injuring More Than a Dozen People
item.description: The incident Friday evening shut down the Montclair-Boonton Line in Montclair, N.J.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

item.title: Elise Stefanik Tried Everything to Please Trump. He Still Jilted Her.
item.description: The G.O.P. congresswoman who ran as a moderate but became an “ultra MAGA” Trump acolyte ultimately found herself undermined by the president and politically adrift.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elise Stefanik’s tumble from grace crystallized the limits of MAGA loyalty and the risks of building a political identity around President Trump.

item.title: Justice Dept. Will Appeal Dismissal of Comey and James Indictments
item.description: The Trump administration had vowed to fight a judge’s decision to dismiss unrelated criminal charges against James Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and Letitia James, the attorney general of New York.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: William B. Plowman/NBCUniversal, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A federal judge last month dismissed the criminal case against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, on the grounds that Lindsey Halligan had been unlawfully appointed to a top prosecutor position.

item.title: Emily Korzenik, Rabbi Who Took a Bar Mitzvah to Poland, Dies at 96
item.description: Part of the first generation of women ordained in America, she presided over the first bar mitzvah in Krakow, still scarred by the Holocaust, in decades. It did not go smoothly.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Thomas McDonald for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik in Stamford, Conn., in 2003. For 25 years she presided over the Fellowship for Jewish Learning, a congregation there.

item.title: Brooklyn Man Accused of Stealing $16 Million in Crypto From Victims
item.description: From a house in Sheepshead Bay, Ronald Spektor bilked about 100 people across the United States, prosecutors say. Then, he went online to brag.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Gonzalez, the district attorney for Brooklyn, said prosecutors would try to track down the missing funds.

item.title: Metro-North and LIRR Commuters to Be Fined for ‘Repeatedly’ Activating Tickets on Train
item.description: Passengers on Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road trains could face $8 fines if they keep waiting until after the train leaves to activate their mobile tickets.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times
item.media:description: There was no set number of late activations or late ticket purchases that would trigger the charge, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

item.title: NY Gov. Kathy Hochul to Sign Prison Reform Bill After Beatings and Deaths
item.description: Prison guards have been accused of more than 120 acts of brutality that amounted to torture in the past decade in New York, a Times investigation found.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes and Jan Ransom
item.category: New York State Commission of Correction
State Correctional Officers and Police Benevolent Assn
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corrections officers viciously beat to death a handcuffed prisoner, Robert L. Brooks, at the Marcy Correctional Facility near Utica, N.Y., last year.

item.title: Bumpy Rollout for New Gates Meant to Stop Subway Fare Evasion
item.description: At a demonstration of devices designed to replace turnstiles, one rider got hit in the neck, and another sneaked through without paying.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.media:credit: Marco Postigo Storel for The New York Times
item.media:description: In addition to combating fare evasion, the new type of gates are expected to make coming and going easier for riders with disabilities, as well as those with strollers or suitcases.

item.title: He Said He Was Not Close With Epstein. His Emails Suggest Otherwise.
item.description: Andrew Farkas, a New York City real estate mogul, had assured investors that his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein was for business only.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Cindy Ord/Getty Images
item.media:description: Emails obtained by The New York Times revealed that Andrew Farkas referred to himself as among Jeffrey Epstein’s best friends.

item.title: ICE Allows Democratic Lawmakers Inside Migrant Cells in New York City
item.description: The immigration agency had barred elected officials from the holding facilities. A federal judge this week said they must be given access.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Olivia Bensimon
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Daniel Goldman on Friday visited immigrant holding cells at 26 Federal Plaza in New York City.

item.title: Museum of the Earth and Its Fossil Collection Fight Their Own Extinction
item.description: A funding crisis at the Museum of the Earth and the Paleontological Research Institution in Ithaca, N.Y., could scatter priceless specimens and end nearly a century of pioneering research.
item.dc:creator: Becky Ferreira and Kristian Thacker
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Cast Says Goodbye to the Netflix Series
item.description: Nearly a decade after the hit sci-fi horror series debuted, cast members including Finn Wolfhard, Gaten Matarazzo and Maya Hawke gathered in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Lanna Apisukh
item.media:description: Members of the “Stranger Things” cast, above, said they planed to watch the series finale together.

item.title: Mamdani Names Deputy Mayors for Housing and Economic Justice
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City’s mayor-elect, tapped Leila Bozorg, a longtime public official and development advocate, and Julie Su, who served as acting secretary of labor in the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani announced on Friday the appointments of Julie Su, left, and Leila Bozorg, center, at a garage on Staten Island that will be converted into affordable housing.

item.title: Trump-Appointed Judge Flays ICE Over Conditions in Long Island Lockup
item.description: A detainee and eight others were held in a tiny room with an open toilet in freezing, filthy conditions.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Erron Anthony Clarke was detained by ICE in November, and held in detention at the Alphonse M. D’Amato U.S. Courthouse in Central Islip, N.Y.

item.title: The New School Seeks Path to Survival Amid Falling Enrollment and Money Woes
item.description: The New York City university has embarked on an overhaul that some professors and students say imperils its standing as a bastion of the liberal arts.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.category: Parsons the New School for Design
item.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students and faculty members at the New School, including Danielle Twiss, a doctoral student studying Marxist political economy, rallied over budget cuts prompted by the university’s budget woes.
